name: Australian Magpie
overview: A familiar and widespread bird known for its loud, melodious carolling and bold behaviour. Common in urban parks and rural areas.
identification: Medium-sized black-and-white bird with a sturdy build and red eyes. Males and females look similar but differ slightly in back colouration.
behaviour: Highly territorial, particularly during breeding season when they may swoop at perceived threats. Intelligent and capable of complex social interactions.
feeding: Insects, small animals, carrion, and food scraps. Often forages on the ground.

name: Sulphur-crested Cockatoo
overview: Large, noisy white cockatoo with a distinctive yellow crest. Commonly seen in flocks in both urban and rural areas of Australia.
identification: White plumage, yellow crest, black beak and feet. Large and conspicuous, especially when calling.
behaviour: Highly social and intelligent, known for loud calls and destructive behaviour (e.g., chewing wood). Often roosts communally.
feeding: Seeds, nuts, fruits, berries, roots, and cultivated crops. Also scavenges food in urban settings.

name: Rainbow Lorikeet
overview: Vibrantly coloured parrot found in coastal regions, often seen in pairs or noisy flocks in flowering trees.
identification: Bright blue head and belly, green wings and back, orange-yellow breast. Medium-sized parrot with a curved beak.
behaviour: Fast-flying, gregarious, and highly active. Feeds in flowering trees and nests in tree hollows.
feeding: Nectar, pollen, fruits, and soft seeds. Uses a specialised brush-tipped tongue to feed on nectar.

name: Eastern Rosella
overview: A brightly coloured parrot with a red head and white cheek patch. Common in woodlands, farmlands, and suburban gardens.
identification: Red head, white cheeks, yellow underparts, green rump, and blue wings. Striking and easily recognisable.
behaviour: Usually seen in pairs or small groups. Forages mostly on the ground but nests in tree hollows.
feeding: Seeds, fruits, buds, nectar, and insects.

name: Superb Fairywren
overview: A small, social bird with striking blue plumage in males during the breeding season. Frequently seen flitting in shrubs and gardens.
identification: Breeding males have vivid blue and black plumage; females and non-breeding males are brown with a dull blue tail.
behaviour: Forms social groups with one breeding male and several helper birds. Active and restless, with constant tail flicking.
feeding: Insects, spiders, and small invertebrates. Forages close to the ground.

name: Brown Thornbill
overview: Information about this species is currently limited. Further ecological and behavioral studies are required.

overview: Information about this species is currently limited. Further ecological and behavioral studies are required.
